agreed; the 8-24 hrs of training does little to support you after you get your waiver. the only "check-in" many prescribing docs get are the random audits from the dea. some states *do* have support systems for early prescribers w/ mentoring, but not tied to the waiver per se.
i thought that was the point.

supply, and especially supply networks, drives a lot of substance use patterns. see 's work on heroin use in california being largely black tar, in northeast largely white powder. largely due to cartel & illicit drug supply chains.

meth use is still very regional. little to none outside of certain demographics here in connecticut. cocaine (esp crack) still the stimulant of choice. i've asked frontline clinicians & harm reduction folks, and it's their experience too.

which is ultimately why i say xthex - it's just bad policy with a bad history - and don't tie that to other needed and important efforts (ie the mate act - hr9474). yes, we increase funding for addiction training for medical professionals; make it mandatory, but still xthex.
she's pretty open about her thoughts regarding people with opioid use disorder ->

also, fwiw, supporting docs new to prescribing or actively prescribing is an important & good goal, but that shouldn't or need to be tied to the x-waiver structure, which in-and-of-itself is bad policy tied to historical other-ing of people with addiction.
- maintaining a separate system for people with oud "reduces stigma"? would be interested to hear how that logic works.
understood; we'll be around.

where there's a will (aka money, $$$, ), there's a way.
yes, absolutely, but 1) i don't think drug courts fit that bucket & 2) don't oversell interventions - if there's no data, just say there's no data, and the equity/justice proposition is sufficient.

i don't know the research/literature on the educational program side. i was more speaking to the corollaries for my concerns for how people talk about drug courts. also the "value" of drug courts in-and-of-themselves is not nearly the same as the "value" of education.
3) in a world of finite resources, i don't think drug courts (which feel good but are unclear if effective), should be where we should sinking our drug-treatment money.

2) drug courts *feel* like they should work (from correctional system & non-court user population), but that's revealing more of our biases & preconceptions than actually how they work. we *trust* judges & correctional systems to provide a guiding hand towards better tx outcomes.

1) the flaws in the studies (in our much teased systematic review) of drug court outcomes are similar to the one's he's quoting on prison ed programs. biased designs that really can't tease out the "causal" effect of drug courts. few rcts, poorly designed observational studies.
- maybe a suburban, wealthy democrat won't have our urban folk's best interests in mind after all? (see also lamont's belt-tightening around social services despite improved state receipts).

i haven’t heard that. inpatient tx should be an option, but not the only one or forced. esp for folks w oud in new haven, why chose that when you have a low barrier methadone tx that’s available regardless?

though probably the *long term* benefit (to everyone) might be preventing people moving into the revolving door/high-use group. one theory for nh’s less successful lead, is that the high-use group felt no “stick” from letting things play out on the non-diversion, status quo path.

not that lead does this, but the incentive might be *higher* for the first time arrestee - the first time arrested, booked, potentially sentenced has more individual impact than, say, the 10th time. yet the system, it might want to focus on the revolving door/high-use group.
folks like  - who has his pulse on albany lead and ct related stuff - or  - who was part of the new haven lead evaluation - may have some more insights.

it has had a lot of trouble getting off the ground here (uptake has been super low). many community members are concerned that implementation here has been to top-down & law enforcement heavy. need more engagement with community partners.

that recommendation has a lot packed in there - reforming lead! increased treatment access! safe injection! decriminalization! - if the mayor & new haven can do even parts of that, i have a lot of hope we’ll be ahead of the curve.
also appreciate the note on decriminalizing possession of buprenorphine & methadone a la what's happening in vt/burlington. it's a good idea.

everyone - city hall, alders, cga, ct dot - should be working on making our cities more pedestrian friendly & less car-focused. this piece, diagonal crossing, is only a part of it. & yes, pedestrian-focused design & law is a passion for many. (see recent  & nhi piece)

i disagree, especially in this case. people are crossing on the diagonal (when traffic is stopped in both directions) because it is generally safe & more efficient. the law & urban design should follow the natural flow of foot traffic.

people are *already* crossing on the diagonal at those intersections (esp church & chapel). adding signals, crosswalks, & signs to that end could *increase* safety. (& avoid more dumb pedestrian tickets)

fair 'nuff, but at least that would avoid needing to change the law. if there was enough $$(grant opportunity?) perhaps it could be done - for example at least in the main intersections around the green - as a pilot?

i'm looking at the cga code now; it clearly says pedestrians can't cross on the diagonal (in absence of a crosswalk). if crosswalks were made diagonal, then potentially a pedestrian could cross on the diagonal (within the crosswalk), no?

thank you for your efforts & highlighting this important intervention. has the doc released any numbers on how many people they're currently treating and if the mat program has been expanded to all the doc facilities?

we're not doing enough for people being released from our prisons & jails. yes, the state passed legislation to fund mat in ct's prisons & jails. time for an update. how many people are they treating? how many facilities is it happening at?

it looks like in their methods "structured diagnoses" meant "provider-entered billing diagnosis; provider-entered encounter diagnosis or problem list entry; or diagnosis code from returned claims." clearly not a "gold standard" by any means.
clearly better systems needed to accurately reflect both clinical decision making that is happening (& not reflected in chart diagnoses) & potential added diagnostic assistance from ai-based systems.

absolutely it means *a lot* especially for research & quality metrics that are claims-based. we are in the process of writing up our manuscript where we went the other way looking at oud dx. icd-10 dx's *very* inaccurate compared to hand-reviewed charts.

agree, most frontline folks know that problem lists/diagnoses are....problematic. though "structured diagnoses" likely don't reflect all the clinical decision making, no? clinicians may be acting on data that ai is picking up even if not reflected in icd-9/10 diagnoses input.

important for ct - even as we hit lows in incarcerated populations (~12,000 -> a 26 year low) we can't call it a "win" if large number of people still in some form of community carceral supervision. parole/probation have real consequences on health, employment, etc.

absolutely, control & barriers for poor people w addiction. compassion & fewer restrictions for the non-poor. also, that gov cuomo cites costs concerns tacitly acknowledges that for the medicaid population, dead poor people are cheaper than living poor people on buprenorphine.

my respect for castro as a candidate sky-rocketed when he met with people currently incarcerated as a presidential candidate. important acknowledgment of incarcerated people as fellow citizens and members of our community.

not to mention all the other profit-making in "public sector prisons" (eg phone charges, food provision, healthcare provision, etc.).
fascinating study; as you all note in your discussion, would be interesting to look at suicide mortality using a similar methodology. one would have to imagine a similar (depressing) trend.

agreed. and the “do they work” frame is often limited to carceral/criminal justice objectives & not health outcomes. ie recidivism or program graduation & not treatment retention or death

agreed, but where were other physicians, the ama, acp, or other physician groups in making that majority position heard? most doctors would support this type of legislation that helps our patients avoid out-of-network surprise billing, but we need to make our voices heard.
fellow docs, we need to take a good look in the mirror. our health care (non)system is broken & our guild-based, wealth protection tendencies are part of the problem.

in this way the nhs (via nice) is arguably *more* innovative than us medical care. also look at integrated systems in the us, such as the va or kaiser or geisenger. all very *innovative* but not developing new drugs.

i think it depends on what you mean by “medical innovation.” lots of opportunity to innovate in how we deliver (or better deliver) things we know already work. innovation is not limited to small molecules/drugs but also the actual delivery and structure of medical care.
what drives yale? the revenue (nih & clinical) from the medical school/hospital. what does that mean for the status quo with respect to our broken health care system? fight change.

rare cases of crimes committed by people out on bail, far outweighed by benefit of keeping many more people in the community prior to their trials. decrease likelihood of plea, keep jobs, keep families intact.

success of reform in connecticut, new york city, & philadelphia speaks against you. on basic principles, people, not yet convicted, should not be held behind bars because they are poor. bail doesn’t benefit public safety, only benefits bail bondsmen.
my hope is the success of cj reform in connecticut so far ( incarcerated populations, crime rates) will grease the wheels for further reform.

also, worth reading the article on how the "self-healing" system of judicial/prosecutorial discretion (& likely the bail bonds industry) de-fanged previous efforts in the state on bail reform. need to anticipate and avoid these mistakes going forward.

severe hypona w hctz? this has not been my experience prescribing hctz as a general internist especially at starting doses. wouldn’t recommend cavalier prescribing of acei’s or even chlorthalidone though. electrolyte disturbances more common with those agents.

as a primary care doc, i’d say hctz is probably fine. risk of electrolyte changes fairly low & unlike acei no real need to get labs after starting to monitor electrolyte changes (though would get for ckd screening). amlodipine is also a fine choice.

just give me the data!

i think this is real & i’m struggling with it. so much of our efforts focused on treatment seeking folks, but likely 50-60% of ods are among people who don’t touch the system. is decrim & safe-supply the key?

to ’s point, if it’s coerced treatment and you take away the stick, where’s the investment in sustained recovery? i’m sure judges believe their paternal influence & the power of their positive validation lingers, but...

mortality would likely be a first step & relatively easy to follow (high risk population, but rare event). in medicaid expansion states could link to medicaid claims data. alternatively state mental health agencies might have data sources.
i will ask paul. we’re in the process of writing up our manuscript now.
passed duke irb.
rct im naltrexone v po naltrexone. argument was that it was better than “treatment as usual”
definitely *harder* to look & few longterm outcomes are criminal-justice focused (recidivism). needs to be looked at. (full disclosure, i’m part of paul’s team)

furthermore evaluations of drug courts at minimum evaluate tx access while *in* court but very few look at retention *after* graduation. have to imagine huge drop off, but it’s an unknown.

varies widely. in nyc - 100% they ok & offer treatment. that said heard a presentation from a group in nc where drug court was randomizing people w oud to po naltrexone (proven inffective tx) which the ethics of stills enrages me.
for those who “fail” can be re-traumatizing and set back recovery

many (most?) drug courts do not allow medications for oud (not sure about mass.) and i’m cynical about their net benefit. yes, help some who self-select & graduate, but unclear harms (not well studied) for folks who don’t graduate. could be *worse* than going straight to jail.

it costs taxpayers more to *not* do it. both because it’s cost effective, evidence-based treatment (reduced acute healthcare costs, reduced recidivism, reduced deaths), but also because they will be sued if they don’t. oh, and it’s the right thing to do.
agreed

my sense is that codac has been a good partner in ri, as has  in new haven, ct. that said, the logistical burden is *heavy* - navigating regulations, licensing, and union-rules, let alone the ins & outs of jail-based medical care
as a current director of a jail-based otp (that's been functioning since the 70's), this would be news to

unfortunately, this doesn’t surprise me. much discretion is allowed by front line providers. need not just knowledge (though clearly lacking) but also attitudinal change. probably true across many stigmatized clinical situations.
very cool - welcome to new haven & yale!

thanks for the close read,  & i would place  - as you have pointed out - & it’s students arms in this lineage. both through direct connections & as part of the larger revival of interest in activism amongst medical trainees.
i will reach out to paul (he made the slides).
not yet; this conference presentation was our first dissemination, but we're working on the manuscript now to disseminate more broadly.
i was disappointed in this when scheduling was invoked as a “reasonable” way to classify substances in this talk at amersa2019
also, having read many of the evaluations, even the personal improvement is oversold as evidence. research of outcomes biased and under appreciate potential harms to people who “fail” them.

drug courts are courts. a fatal flaw to the model. not clear to me if further investment in that model; agreed all $$going into courts/prisons/jails need to be directed elsewhere, ie into the community.

adult drug court evaluations in the us emphasize criminal-justice priorities (ie recidivism) and not health outcomes (ie treatment & mortality); real unknown how they impact overdoses. important area for change!  presenting our work at amersa2019
i think you mean
this is not a “slight” change. the dark gray road jerseys were great. this is disappointing.
dbacks jerseys used to be innovative, now they are just boring like everyone else’s. no dark gray, no scales, no weird piping.
not in our sample. the ’s on bupe for pain (not ud) are generally low & not represented in this sample.
lots of confusion at amersa2019 -    & me all in the same room at the same time. which bald white-guy beardo is which?

also, fewer harm reduction & voices of folks w lived experience this year compared to last year’s amersa. need to keep these voices centered - *especially* as addiction medicine & research become more mainstream. $from nida/samhsa has potential to push these voices out.
agreed - that hit wrong. why would it matter?

true - context important - folks who got started on moud - high levels of supporting documentation (not surprising). though patients on ltot in primary care who get “diagnosed” w oud, a coin-flip if the diagnosis is valid (based on what’s in the chart)
mds/researchers need to acknowledge racism embedded in drug scheduling. doesn’t need to be “reformed” - it needs to be abandoned. especially reflecting after ’s powerful talk yesterday.

amersa2019 - talk on psychedelics, currently talking about therapeutic role. compared to societal “harms” of other substance - such as crack cocaine - need to acknowledge structural racism that make those harms. need to not privilege substances used by white-folks.

in healthcare settings also complicated by opioids prescribed for pain. someone can get dx’ed w “oud” for some behaviors that are not addiction - especially in an environment where folks are getting nudged to get folks *off* opioids for pain.

noted

agreed - fwiw we didn’t even look at problem list diagnoses (which have *a lot* of garbage) & these were only “diagnoses” linked to an encounter. obviously if oud already on the problem list, easy to perpetuate errors, but these were also “new” diagnoses.

large % looked like real errors (>50%). eg person admitted for aud & “diagnosed” w oud in a group encounter for oend. or the lab entered the “diagnosis” to bill a u-tox. nothing else in chart c/w oud in 120 day window.

also, we were pretty liberal with what counted as “sufficient” documentation & looked at all records within a 120 day window of initial oud encounter. if any evidence of oud, got counted as “sufficient”.

agreed - that icd-10 has “opioid dependence” and “opioid abuse” (which don’t match up w dsm-v) creates systems errors. people code “dependence” when they mean physical dependence, but those diagnoses get swept into oud on the back end.

over 35% of new diagnoses of opioid use disorder are potential misclassifications. over-diagnosis has real consequences for reported va quality metrics and research that use these oud numbers uncritically. our work presented at amersa2019
